messageBody:
Well, I tried a test app (following) and it worked for me. Without the
fixClasspath() call though, it didn't. So, perhaps including the
project_resources subdir does not works as automagically as I thought
(because I tried to include just its dir and that didn't work).

Have you tried the fixClasspath/setClasspath method yet?

-Jason


********** TEST * CODE **********
//imports

public class Tester extends TestRunner {
public Tester() {
super();
}
public static void main(String[] args) {
String[] newargs = new String[1];
try{
fixClasspath();
newargs[0] = Class.forName("<a class name>").toString();
TestRunner.main(newargs);
} catch (Exception ex){
ex.toString();
}
private static void fixClasspath(){
Workspace workspace = ToolEnv.connectToWorkspace();
Object[] classpath = workspace.getClassPathEntries();
Object[] projects = workspace.getProjects();
Object[] newClasspath = new Object[classpath.length +
projects.length];

//add the projects to the new classpath
System.arraycopy(projects, 0, newClasspath, 0, projects.length);

//add the original classpath to the new classpath
System.arraycopy(classpath, 0, newClasspath, projects.length,
classpath.length);

try {
workspace.setClassPath(newClasspath);
} catch(IvjException e) {
e.printStackTrace();
}
}
}
}
